Abstract
A prominent ultraviolet (UV)-absorbing compound of unknown identity was discovered in
the aqueous humor of birds, believed to be a key UV-filter of the eyes of aves. The
compound´s concentration correlates with species´ natural flight altitudes, with the highest
concentrations found in goose chamber fluid (up to 10,000 m flight altitude). We present
evidence that the compound is 5,6-dihydroxyindole (DHI), based on analysis using liquid
chromatography, UV spectroscopy, fluorescence spectroscopy, nuclear magnetic
resonance spectroscopy, mass spectrometry and X-ray crystallography. DHI is a precursor
of melanin (the key UV-absorbing polymer in biology), produced in the proximity of the
chamber fluid. Identification was greatly challenged by the compound´s tendency to
polymerize when enriched. DHI may function not only as nature´s UV-filter in the skin, but
also as "sunglasses" as well.
Keywords: Bird; Eye; UV; Melanin; 5,6-dihydroxyindole
Significance Statement
Nature provides species with various solutions for protecting the eyes from sun radiation.
For example, the eye contains compounds that absorb UV radiation, like ascorbic acid. But
what about the more extreme cases like geese, which fly as high as 10,000 meters (above
the Himalayas)? In the aqueous humor of birds, an unknown compound provides a major
contribution for UV-absorbance. The higher the bird can fly, the more of this compound is
present, suggesting its significance to Nature. We have identified this compound as being
5,6-dehydroxyindole. This compound is also a building block of melanin, a skin protector.
Hence, using various analytical/spectroscopic techniques, we have unraveled "sunglasses"
that evolution has provided aves. It is conceivable that this compound could be used for
humans as well, e.g. as a component in both contact lenses and intraocular lenses.
